div.p: ANTONIO: Having a plan in place can help us overcome a state dependent learning skill.
ANTONIO: But what if we are in relationships that are state-dependent, like friendships or romantic relationships? Once again, we'll go to Ray.
RAY: When a friendship or relationship is formed around alcohol or drug use it's possible for the relationship itself to become state dependent.
RAY: This means when we use we feel closer and have more fun. It might be hard to imagine even being together without using.
RAY: And when we remove the alcohol or drugs we may find the relationship is no longer fulfilling or that the person is no longer fun to be with.
RAY: But, If both people in the relationship are committed to changing their alcohol or drug use, and are committed to the relationship, it can work;
they just need to rediscover each other soberâ€”almost like it's a new relationship.
ANTONIO: Thanks, Ray. So, once we become aware that a skill, or set of skills, has become state dependent, we can put a plan in place to re-learn it without making high-risk choices.
ANTONIO: It might take a lot of practice, and patience, but it will get better if we keep making low-risk choices. Think of it as making an investment in our relationships, our future, and ourselves.
